other_tests.findings: Possible small, fixed, apicalâ€“inferior myocardial infarct surrounded by mild ischemia; small, posterobasal septal, nontransmural infarct with apical hypokinesis.
Normal rhythm with small inferior-lead Q waves of uncertain clinical significance and no acute changes.

Segmental left ventricular apical hypokinesis or akinesis; hypokinetic areas in anterior and midseptal regions; echodense areas in left ventricular apex indicative of trabeculations; left ventricular ejection fraction was 60 percent; small circumferential pericardial effusion.

other_tests.date: Six weeks after new symptoms developed
other_tests.findings: Trace-to-mild tricuspid insufficiency; multilobular mass of echoes, 4.3 by 3.1 cm, invading the tricuspid annulus; segmental right ventricular dysfunction without dilatation; normal left ventricular cavity size; moderate pericardial effusion.

Dense infiltrate of large, atypical lymphoid cells with appearance of centroblasts and immunoblasts; tumor cells were CD20-positive and CD3-negative, consistent with B-cell lymphoma; approximately 95% of tumor cells were positive for Ki-67.
Diffuse large-B-cell lymphoma that was EBV-positive.

other_tests.date: Eight weeks after start of chemotherapy
other_tests.findings: The right atrial mass had decreased in size to 1.7 by 3.0 cm; it still extended into the tricuspid valve but no longer obstructed it; pericardium appeared free of disease; ejection fraction decreased from 60 percent to 45 percent.
other_tests.changes_over_time: Size of tumor decreased post-chemotherapy, though ejection fraction decreased.
